channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: New Immigration Limits Cause Anxiety in Families and Businesses
item.description: President Trump’s move to suspend some green cards could make it harder for many immigrants to reunite with loved ones or work in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson and Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: A closed immigration services field office in Tukwila, Wash., last month.

item.title: ‘I Am Beyond Disturbed’: Internal Dissent as States Reopen Despite Virus
item.description: Several mayors and employers have asked residents to ignore the Georgia governor’s declaration that some businesses can resume operation while the coronavirus lingers.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Robert Willett/The News & Observer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters on Tuesday called on Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina to follow other Southern states by reopening.

item.title: Roommates in Coronavirus Era: ‘Friends’ It Isn’t
item.description: Living with a roommate has always included some drama. But these days, once petty grievances about cleanliness or visitors have morphed into arguments over safety.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a week of wearing pajamas all day in their Atlanta apartment, Naomi Nagel and Michelle Topping decided they had to do something to force them to change clothes, and to lift their moods. They created a “spirit month” calendar.

item.title: During Coronavirus, Unions Resist New Demands on Teachers
item.description: Educators say they want to teach from home during the pandemic, but are fighting to limit work hours and counter demands that they consider unreasonable.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Becky Atherton Dukes, an art teacher in Tulsa, Okla., seen here in 2018. She is now juggling care for her two children and responsibilities for her remote classroom.

item.title: Common Thread Tying Together 2019’s ‘Most Challenged’ Books: L.G.B.T.Q. Issues
item.description: Eight of the 10 titles identified in the American Library Association’s annual ranking of the most frequently banned or protested books featured L.G.B.T.Q. subject matter.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: The HBO host John Oliver with a copy of “A Day in the Life of Marlon Bundo,” which imagines a gay romance involving Vice President Mike Pence’s rabbit.

item.title: New U.S. Treatment Guidelines for Covid-19 Don’t See Much Progress
item.description: A panel of experts said there was insufficient evidence about many drugs that have been considered as possible remedies for coronavirus patients, including some President Trump has advocated.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The panel specifically advised against the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine, which was associated with an increased risk of death.

item.title: House Readies Historic Changes to Allow Remote Voting During Pandemic
item.description: Democratic leaders plan to temporarily dispatch with two centuries of precedent as the coronavirus upends American life and government.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: An empty hallway leading to the House chamber in the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Threatens Press Freedom Around the World, Report Says
item.description: The United States, which ranked 45th out of 180 countries and territories, and Brazil were becoming models of hostility toward the news media, according to the World Press Freedom Index.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: The New York Times, via Reporters Without Borders

item.title: ‘I’m Just Living a Nightmare’: Oil Industry Braces for Devastation
item.description: Across the United States, companies are laying off workers, shutting down wells and preparing for a prolonged slump as oil prices tumble.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss

item.title: The Quiet Hand of Conservative Groups in the Anti-Lockdown Protests
item.description: Groups in a loose coalition have tapped their networks to drive up turnout at recent rallies in state capitals and financed lawsuits, polling and research to combat the stay-at-home orders.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel, Jim Rutenberg and Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: People protested at the Washington State Capitol in Olympia on Sunday. Organizers see the events as unifying social and fiscal conservatives as well as civil libertarians.

item.title: Coronavirus Infections May Not Be Uncommon, Tests Suggest
item.description: Two preliminary efforts to survey citizens for antibodies to the virus have produced controversial results.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: A health care worker takes a blood sample for an antibody test in Bolinas, Calif., on Monday. Elsewhere in the state, testing in two countries suggested that 2 percent to 4 percent of residents may have been infected.

item.title: What’s Next for Restaurants Shut Out of Paycheck Protection Program
item.description: Owners of many small, independent restaurants were passed over by a federal loan program. Now they fear that a new round may not solve their problems.
item.dc:creator: Pete Wells
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renato Poliafito, who owns a small Brooklyn bakery and cafe, says he was denied a federal small-business loan because the fund had run dry.

item.title: Dan Scavino Promoted as Meadows Shuffles White House Communications Team
item.description: Mr. Scavino, who is said to be the only White House aide with access to the president’s personal Twitter account, will now be deputy chief of staff for communications.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Scavino, one of the original aides in President Trump’s 2016 campaign, has been the White House director of social media.

item.title: Puerto Rico Lags Behind in Coronavirus Testing
item.description: A strict lockdown has required much sacrifice from Puerto Ricans, whose patience with the slow pace of testing is running out.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health care workers receiving the coronavirus rapid test at a drive-thru site at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Puerto Rico on Monday in San Juan, P.R.

item.title: Israelis Find Little to Love in Their New Government, Except No More Elections
item.description: Right-wingers felt betrayed by Netanyahu’s surrender of half the government. Gantz voters felt betrayed by almost everything else in a power-sharing deal.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Installing an election billboard in Tel Aviv, Israel, in February. While few are pleased with the coalition government, Israelis are in agreement on one thing — no more elections.

item.title: How Many Coronavirus Infections? Rewards for Testing May Provide an Answer
item.description: Economists say incentives could overcome hurdles in gauging the overall coronavirus infection and mortality rates from a limited population sample.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Porter
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A drive-through coronavirus testing site in California. Establishing infection and mortality rates will require testing to go beyond those with symptoms or at risk.

item.title: Christian Health Sharing Group Is Target of Customer Lawsuits
item.description: State regulators in New York and elsewhere are also trying to stop the marketing of plans they say look like health insurance but offer no guarantees of coverage.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: One recent lawsuit filed in federal court in Missouri accused Trinity Healthshare for having “sold inherently unfair and deceptive health care plans to Missouri residents.”

item.title: Senate Approves Aid for Small-Business Loan Program, Hospitals and Testing
item.description: The Senate passed a $484 billion relief package, after Democrats and Trump administration officials finalized an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Senator Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, speaking to reporters on Tuesday at the Capitol.

item.title: Republican-Led Review Backs Intelligence Findings on Russian Interference
item.description: A new Senate report undercuts claims by President Trump and his allies that Obama-era officials sought to undermine him while investigating Russia’s 2016 election meddling.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Senator Richard M. Burr, the Intelligence Committee chairman, noted that Russia had continued efforts to interfere in American politics.

item.title: Sheriff Told Teen to Take Down Posts About Coronavirus, Family’s Lawsuit Says
item.description: Amyiah Cohoon, 16, was asked to remove Instagram posts about what she believed was her experience with Covid-19 because it upset some parents at her school, the lawsuit said.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:description: Amyiah Cohoon in the hospital

item.title: As Coronavirus Spreads, Poison Hotlines See Rise in Accidents With Cleaning Products
item.description: A new study suggests a link between the increase and recommendations to clean and disinfect.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein

item.title: Coronavirus in Wisconsin: At Least 7 Cases Tied to Election Day Voting
item.description: Milwaukee health officials said six voters and one poll worker contracted the coronavirus from participating in Election Day, which was held despite a stay-at-home order issued throughout the state.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lined up to vote at Riverside High School in Milwaukee on April 7.

item.title: F.D.A. Authorizes First In-Home Test for Coronavirus
item.description: The test, sold by LabCorp, would first be made available to health care and other front-line workers, the company said.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Natasha Singer
item.media:description: A LabCorp test at a drive-through testing site in North Charleston, S.C., last month. The company’s new test, called Pixel, will be available for consumers in most states.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: Antibody Testing in L.A.
item.description: Tuesday: Early study results suggest the virus may be more prevalent than previously known. Also: An assignment shift for the Navy hospital ship Mercy.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A health care worker taking a blood sample for antibody testing before doing a nasal swab diagnostic Covid-19 test at a drive-through at Mesa Park in the town of Bolinas.

item.title: The Latest Fashion Accessory in Miami: A Luxury Condo
item.description: Upscale brands are licensing their names to developers in South Florida who are looking to stand out in a crowded market.
item.dc:creator: C. J. Hughes
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fendi collaborated with the interior designer Fanny Haim on the beachfront Fendi Chateau Residences in Surfside, Fla.

item.title: On Politics: Trump Pledges to Halt Immigration
item.description: Lawmakers argue over virus testing, and restrictions begin to lift: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Coronavirus, Immigration, Kim Jong-un: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here's what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Senate Passes $484 Billion Aid Package
item.description: Oil prices cratered. Mayors in Georgia pushed back on the governor’s decision to reopen the state. President Trump announced a 60-day pause in issuing green cards.

item.title: Coronavirus Roommate Tips: The Dos and Don'ts
item.description: In most zombie movies, there’s usually someone who endangers the lot. Don’t let that be you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Arthur Adamczyk shares hand sanitizer with his roommate Nash Petrovic on their rooftop in Brooklyn during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Past Into Present: 4 Journeys That Changed Us
item.description: We asked four of our contributors to write about trips that shaped who they are today, and that inspire them now, in these housebound days.
item.dc:creator: Ron Stodghill, Charly Wilder, Sarah Khan and Bonnie Tsui

item.title: Vote by Mail in Wisconsin Helped a Liberal Candidate, Upending Old Theories
item.description: A large shift from in-person to mail voting, as happened in the state because of the coronavirus, had been thought to create little advantage for either party. A Times analysis found otherwise.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Mark Hoffman/Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Workers counted absentee ballots at the Milwaukee Election Commission this month. The city normally has 180 in-person polling places, but for Wisconsin’s elections this month it had only five.

item.title: How The Times Covered the First Earth Day, 50 Years Ago
item.description: For the first Earth Day, on April 22, 1970, The New York Times went big.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain

item.title: The Sound of One Shrimp Snapping
item.description: How climate change is altering nature’s sonic landscape.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker During Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: The S&P 500 dropped more than 3 percent on Tuesday, its biggest daily decline in three weeks.

item.title: Pastor Faces Assault Charge After Dispute With Protester Over Social Distancing
item.description: Tony Spell backed up a church bus toward a man who had been protesting outside Life Tabernacle Church, which has defied Louisiana’s ban on public gatherings, the authorities said. He did not hit the man.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Pastor Tony Spell driving a bus with local residents as they leave the Life Tabernacle megachurch after attending Easter Mass, challenging state orders against assembling in large groups to prevent the spread of coronavirus in Louisiana.

item.title: Coronavirus World Updates: Pandemic Is Worsening Global Poverty
item.description: A new report warns that the number of people facing acute hunger could double. In southern Italy, the pandemic is choking an already fragile economy.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Milan on Sunday. Coronavirus overwhelmed health care systems in the north of Italy.

item.title: 2020 Campaign Fund-Raising: Biden Campaign Nearly $187 Million Behind Trump
item.description: New fund-raising figures show the depth of the financial hole in which Mr. Biden finds himself against a president and Republican Party that have built up a huge war chest.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a campaign event in McClellanville, S.C., in February.

item.title: Trump Plans to Suspend Immigration to U.S.
item.description: The president portrayed the measure, his most wide-ranging attempt yet to seal off the country from the world, as a bid to save Americans’ jobs amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday at the White House. Late Monday evening, he tweeted that he would sign an “Executive Order to temporarily suspend immigration into the United States!”
